Posts.Content: I saw Dr Joseph Mashni at the Banner Gateway/MD Anderson Center in Gilbert. He is a Urology Oncologist. I highly recommend him and the team that supports him. I wish you and your father the best. Keep us updated please.

Gleason scores 4 cores=6 (3+3) 1 core=7 (3+4) Clinical Stage 1 Bone scan and Pelvic CT were negative 3T MRI 6/20/16 Robotic surgery 7/14/16 Post surgery PSA tests 8/26/16 = .04 psa 9/23/16 = .061 psa 11/17/16 = .12 psa 12/9/16 start cacodex and Lupron 35 sessions of IMRT radiation started Feb 2017 Cacodex and Lupron stopped April 2017 6/26/17 PSA test result <.01ng/ml

Posts.Title: Catheter is out!

Posts.Content: I feel very fortunate to have found this forum. I have reached out and shared some of my story with you but feel even luckier because of all the posts others have shared. This forum offered me support when I really needed it. I thank all of you for that. My recovery has been bumpy at times but not nearly as bad as some of our brothers. My anxiety increased as my first post-radiation PSA test approached. I was both confident and scared to hear the number I have. I am elated to share that I got the best news possible. My test result is <.01ng/ml. I thank God for giving me strength to get through this disease and pray to continue with my healing. Thank all of you for helping me along the way. I know this journey isn't over and will be something I need to deal with for years. I'm just taking a few moments to celebrate the wonderful news I got. With that being said, I hope that my good news can inspire others to have hope in their journey too. Thank you to all! Hammer
Posts.Signature: Born 1963 Father and brother both had PC PSA 3/2014=2.5 3/2015=2.9 3/2016=4.1 Enlarged prostate 3+ years Prostate biopsy 5/2016 5 out of 12 cores were cancer. 4 cores were high PIN. 3 were benign. Gleason scores 4 cores=6 (3+3) 1 core=7 (3+4) Clinical Stage 1 Bone scan and Pelvic CT were negative 3T MRI 6/20/16 Robotic surgery 7/14/16 Post surgery PSA tests 8/26/16 = .04 psa 9/23/16 = .061 psa 11/17/16 = .12 psa 12/9/16 start cacodex and Lupron 35 sessions of IMRT radiation started Feb 2017 Cacodex and Lupron stopped April 2017 6/26/17 PSA test result <.01ng/ml
Posts.Title: Just got great news!

Posts.Content: Hello, I am 53 years old and in good health. I have been very proactive with my prostate health, getting annual exams for several years due to family history. My father was diagnosed with stage 3 PC in the mid 1990's. He passed away 3 years later with prostate, kidney, bone and lung cancers. My older brother was diagnosed with stage 2 PC in 12/2011. He was 63 years old at the time. He had a robotic prostatectomy and has had a very good experience since. As you will see in my signature, I was diagnosed with an enlarged prostate several years ago. My urologist stated my prostate was enlarged, but it did not feel suspicious and my PSA results were at acceptable levels. The only problem I was having was a weak urine flow at times. I was prescribed tamulosin to help with easing my urine flow. It has worked as expected for several years. My PSA tests have climbed steadily over the past few years. In March of 2014 my PSA was 2.5. In March 2015 it was 2.9. In March 2016, it increased again to 4.1. My urologist suggested a prostate biopsy due to the accelerated increase in my last year. On May 3, 2016 I had my prostate biopsy (done under sedation). 12 core samples were taken. The biopsy results came in about a week later. Stage 1 Adenocarcinoma. The Gleason scores were as follows. 4 cores Gleason 6 (3+3) 1 core Gleason 7 (3+4) 4 cores were high grade PIN 3 cores were benign. So, I started doing research on the internet about PC. Wow, is there a ton of info out there. During my research, I stumbled across this Prostate Cancer Forum. What a blessing! I read several of your threads and compared "my story" to them. I felt as though I was learning a lot and the forum helped me formulate at plan. My urologist scheduled me for a full body bone scan and a pelvic CT. My doctor said both scans look good and there is no evidence the cancer has spread. I'm sorry if I'm not using the correct terminology. Based on my research, combined with speaking to my brother and another man I work with, I am leaning toward having a robotic prostatectomy. I have interviewed two surgeons and feel very good about the one I have chosen. I am scheduled to have a 3T MRI on 6/20/16 and then a robotic prostatectomy on 7/14/16. I am nervous about the surgery and possible side effects, but confident this will work out great for me. Again, I want to thank The Prostate Forum members and moderators for this site!!! Hold on...here we go!!!
Posts.Signature: Born 1963 Father and brother both had PC PSA 3/2014=2.5 3/2015=2.9 3/2016=4.1 Enlarged prostate 3+ years Prostate biopsy 5/2016 5 out of 12 cores were cancer. 4 cores were high PIN. 3 were benign. Gleason scores 4 cores=6 (3+3) 1 core=7 (3+4) Clinical Stage 1 Bone scan and Pelvic CT were negative 3T MRI 6/20/16 Robotic surgery 7/14/16 Post surgery PSA tests 8/26/16 = .04 psa 9/23/16 = .061 psa 11/17/16 = .12 psa 12/9/16 start cacodex and Lupron 35 sessions of IMRT radiation started Feb 2017 Cacodex and Lupron stopped April 2017 6/26/17 PSA test result <.01ng/ml

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Hello all...its time for an update! On 6/20 I went in and did the 3T MRI with and without contrast. This procedure took about 30-40 minutes and I felt very comfortable inside the "tube". I just tried to keep my eyes closed and concentrated on slow breathing and remaining as still as I could. I guess I was too relaxed, because I actually started falling asleep, all while the machine was making all that racket! The technician told me I needed to try to stay awake, because my breathing started being deeper, which showed up on the test as movement. Ooops... On 6/24 I went back to see the doctor and go over my MRI results and found that I am very lucky. The test results indicated there is no evidence the cancer has left the prostate. There is no capsular indentation or extracapsular extension. The neurovascular bundles, seminal vesicals and rectal prostatic angle are all unremarkable. My doctor said he was very happy with these results and plans on being aggressive with nerve sparing. What a relief. Anyway, I feel very fortunate that I have many family members and friends praying for me and my family. I also wanted to say that everyone at MD Anderson Cancer Center that has been part of my treatment has been superb. What a great group of people! I just wanted to post my update for those who find themselves fighting PC. I know when I was first diagnosed, I was looking at anything I could just to learn about this disease. I found that reading the stories posted by "us" gave me so much relief. I hope others out there are as lucky as I was with the early detection. I am scheduled for my RALP on 7/14/16. My doctor said I will have one night in the hospital and then released for home the following day. Again, I want to thank everyone that has read and/or commented on my journey. Until later... Hammer

Posts.Title: Catheter is out!

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the responses. I really appreciate the kind words and thoughts you have given me. That is what I really like about the forum...sharing experiences in "our" words. I failed to mention that the doctor I selected works at MD Anderson in Arizona. He is a Urologic Oncologist and has performed several hundred RALP's. I feel very confident in his surgical abilities and in my future. I will keep updating you with my progress. Thanks again! Hammer

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Hello all... After having surgery in July 2016 my PSA tests started to elevate just a few months later. I took 2 weeks of cacodex and a hormone shot in preparation for radiation therapy. February to April 2017 I had 35 sessions of IMRT. Fast forward, I just had my 3rd PSA test since my treatment. June, September and January are all <0.010ng/ml. The days leading up to my recent PSA were nerve racking. I feel so blessed to remain in the zero club. Prayers for all my PCA brothers. Stay positive and jump into the fight! Thanks again for all the support from this forum. Hammer

Posts.Title: Feeling Great!

Posts.Content: Thank you for the responses. I feel lucky to have found this forum. Thanks to all the moderators and people that post their experiences.
Posts.Title: Feeling Great!

Posts.Content: Hello all, I had my RALP in July 2016. I've had 3 post surgery PSA tests done. They were as follows; 8/26 .04psa 9/23 .06psa 11/17 .12psa I am already working with a radiation oncologist and will be receiving salvage radiation. He has gone over many of the possible side effects, but it's hard to know which, if any, of them I will experience. I do hope someone out there can put me at ease. I was speaking with another patient at the doctor today who said his radiation therapy burned and was painful during the procedure. I hope that is a rare issue. Any comments will be appreciated. Thanks! Hammer

Posts.Title: Questions on upcoming salvage radiation

Posts.Content: I pray for peace and comfort for your family. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: I pray for peace and comfort for your family. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: I pray for peace and comfort for your family. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: My experience with the balloons was similar to Rooster22's. There was no pain associated with it, just a little uncomfortable when being inserted. I had none of the side effects (burning urination and urgency to defecate) the doctor said could develop toward the end of my treatments. I think the balloons were vital in maintaining healthy tissues in those areas. The only side effect I did get in about week 6 was I was a little more tired than normal. In fact today is the 1 year anniversary of my last treatment! I'm doing great and received my 4th straight <.01 mg/nl PSA. Good luck to you in your treatments and I pray for success. Hammer
Posts.Title: Your experience rectal balloon with EBRT

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing. I'm sure there is a PCA brother out there that will gain strength from your story.

I was speaking with another patient at the doctor today who said his radiation therapy burned and was painful during the procedure. I hope that is a rare issue. Any comments will be appreciated. Thanks! Hammer
Posts.Signature: Born 1963 Father and brother both had PC PSA 3/2014=2.5 3/2015=2.9 3/2016=4.1 Enlarged prostate 3+ years Prostate biopsy 5/2016 5 out of 12 cores were cancer. 4 cores were high PIN. 3 were benign. Gleason scores 4 cores=6 (3+3) 1 core=7 (3+4) Clinical Stage 1 Bone scan and Pelvic CT were negative 3T MRI 6/20/16 Robotic surgery 7/14/16 Post surgery PSA tests 8/26/16 = .04 psa 9/23/16 = .061 psa 11/17/16 = .12 psa 12/9/16 start cacodex and Lupron 35 sessions of IMRT radiation started Feb 2017 Cacodex and Lupron stopped April 2017 6/26/17 PSA test result <.01ng/ml
